author: ReflectAA
body:
The only industries I’ve invested in the last 10 or so years:

Social media/Ad services (eg: FB, Google)
Multimedia services (Disney, Netflix, Apple)
Consumer Tech (Apple, Seagate, Blackberry)
Microchips (AMD)
Biotech/pharma (eg: NBEV, AMRS, JNJ, MRNA)
Retail
Restaurants
Airlines/Airline-related (DAL, BA)
Auto/Auto-related (GM, UBER, HTZ)
Wireless/internet (CMCSA, AT&T, VZ)
Banking (BAC, WFC)

The examples are just examples, I didn’t invest in all of these companies but I did at least consider all of them.  

And then some industries I stay out of because I haven’t researched and don’t have time or interest in doing so. Which isn’t to say they look like bad industries. Just ones I’m not comfortable touching until I research the whole industry at once:

Payment services (PayPal, Square)
Betting/gaming
Solar energy
Commodities and commodity related goods (oil, gas, diamonds, gold, etc...)
Other areas of tech (graphics like NVidia, tech security like Fortinet, cloud services)

I’m sure there’s way more I’m forgetting.

I also bought a bunch of weekly puts at 234 not long ago and regrettably sold them way too early. 

I am more bearish probably than most of you. I just don't yet see a catalyst for a huge 250+ leg down with CBs yet. I mostly just hold cash and bonds. 

I can't see a justification for buying puts right now with VIX at 45 - seems -ev. 

If you have a huge bankroll and the money to be selling puts this is probably a great time for that. We may even stay relatively flat as the fiscal/monetary moves find an equilibrium with the real economy - we obviously swung in one direction way too fast and now we are reverting- but he much reversion in the question. 

Personally I'm selling cash secured puts on tech I like such as FTNT

author: RipeForInvesting
body:
I've bought companies at much higher P/E values and continued to gain long afterwards.  

NFLX is one for example, that was one that people screamed, "it's overvalued, look at the P/E."....meanwhile my account just kept going up and up regardless of the P/E value at the time.    Same thing with FTNT.  

 I wouldn't call P/E the best way to value a stock.  

PEG on Facebook is sitting at 1.81; that is not exactly high.

Some numbers:

EPS qoq was +101%, 12.8% yoy.  YOY wasn't outstanding but it beat Apple and Google.

CF growth rate is 42% the last 5 years, Revenue growth 41.5%, 

They carry very little debt, great margins and proj growth is somewhere around 34.6%.

Where something is going and how it is managed is more important than isolating some P/E value and declaring it is overvalued.

Best of luck to you as well.

author: w1na
body:
She did a good job, no one could even imagine even 5 years ago where AMD would be today.
When she took office, the cupboard were bare, there was no sales, no good architecture, losing for 2 decade to intel. Since the first athlon x64, they kept releasing bad products most of the time. In just 3 years, she made AMD go from Zero to Hero!

AMD now trading at tremendous numbers, no one thought would be possible ever. Heck just look 7 years back, the share price was about 2 bucks.

If there is any CEO who you feel should earn so much, it’s not people from Moderna, but Lisa Su.

Just to give you an idea, back in 2014 or so, I remember trying to buy AMD shares under 2 euros each (I wanted to get 2000 euro), before the order went through, it asked me for some paperwork confirmation, I then did not go through with the order and never did.

Missed on 1000 shares from AMD. I did not believe back then, although I saw it was incredibly cheap.

author: mechtech
body:
Well this is /r/investing, so buy quality and hold, diversify (beyond just bonds which may or may not have a good future in a zero rate world), and have worldwide exposure/don't arbitrarily lock yourself to your own country.

I actively trade, but in all likelihood in 2040 the investors at the top will likely have stories like "As Waymo got bigger, my ETF kept buying more, and now Waymo is 10 trillion dollars. And as that Chinese electric car company grew and took 1/3 of the 1 billion person Chinese market, my ETF kept buying more on the way up."

Although in that same vein, getting ahead of the tech curve might be one of the few ways for someone outside of the professional investor/institutional world to realistically get ahead. The trick is having the fortitude to hold for 1-2 decades. The financial crisis in '08 blew me out of so many hilariously good positions, like SBAC because the iPhone was just invented and 3G means more cell phone towers... It's not always rocket science. Anyone with some specialized insight into the future, whatever it may be, should consider putting a small well thought out speculative position on and leave it be. Small enough to not hurt if it goes nowhere, but big enough to care enough to check up and manage every few months.

Wow, just looked up an email from over 10 years ago. These names are probably in the mainstream investing language now, but wow... 10-100x if they were held. And it wasn't complex quant investing or anything, just looking ahead, positioning, and waiting.

Quotes from the email circa 10 years ago: "NVDA... They are also making a leap into scientific computing, where there's a lot of money to be made. They're the first major player to enter that arena to fight Intel and AMD in a long time, and their architecture is much more suited to scientific computing than the traditional CPUs that currently rule the top 100 supercomputer list. I think I'll see how that works out before selling NVDA"

"I might want to put some money in AMD as well. They're here to stay and may still be undervalued..."

"Universal Display Corp and LG Display (PANL/LPL) are also the leaders and partners in OLED screen development, which is bound to catch on eventually. Lower power use and much better image quality mean that it's just a matter of time before more devices adopt this new display technology and it becomes a new standard. I actually expect Apple to eventually partner up with LG (I think LG is their main LCD supplier) and use and use an OLED display on either a new product or a new Iphone version, which will kick OLED production into overdrive."

Food for thought... MicroLED is likely going to grow 1000x over the coming decades. AR and LIDAR sensors for AR will probably not just be used for face unlock and will get some killer apps, the next Snapchat or TikTok might be AR based. Self-Driving is going to be powered by thousands of companies, not just NVIDIA and Waymo. Quantum computing? AI providers in the military contracting space? Clean cargo ship tech to get in front of green regulations? It's endless, and so many people know about these little niches of information that very few others do. Even mundane spaces see world changing innovation every day. Getting in front of a curve is inherently speculative but it is also entertaining, educational to follow through development, and can be extremely profitable.

That's my appeal for pulling a few pennies out of the ETF pile and doing some a little different, especially if you have a "wheelhouse" that you know a little bit more about.

author: centered_div
body:
Hey, I'm currently holding and I would like to say they are not dominating the computer processor world. I got in at around 44 during the market drop. They are dwarfed in comparison to Intel, that being said I believe they are going to grow rapidly.

* Amazing CEO Lisa Su brought them from the debts of hell (I'm so funny)
* Their balance sheets look pretty nice similar to Intel in terms of percentages
* Very good name "AMD" is very recognizable (yes believe it or not data shows that a good name has its benefits, source: Peter Lynch?)
* My decision was based less on what analysts and wallstreet was saying and more about what people in the computer community were saying. I browsed many discussions on AMD vs Intel and a majority were praising AMD.

This is obviously a David vs Goliath scenario but I believe AMD will come out on top. Intel has grown complacent and were caught off guard by the growth of AMD/their superior tech. Although AMD is losing the current short-term battle (in terms of stock movement) I still have faith in their products, and especially the CEO.

author: 1monster90
body:
You shouldn't invest money you can't afford to lose. Personally, money in the stock market is money I am considering nonexistent until 2045.   
Don't be greedy but don't be cynical either. I think you could really benefit from making a list of interesting stocks. And from that list try to pick at least 10 stocks that you find promising and buy. Even if it's just 1 share (that way you will be focused on these companies, it's not so much to make a profit than making yourself focus and research these companies. I find it easier to focus on stocks I have at least one share with that stocks I don't own at all).  


Here is my list of shares I'm watching carefully, feel free to research it.  
MSFT, V, MA, NKE, NTDOY, LOGI, SPXL, TQQQ, DOCU,  TRIP, ALGN, F, GME, APPL, NFLX, SBUX, LUV, HS, AMZN, AAL, TMUS, PG,  INTC, QCOM, PYPL, T, ATVI, RSG, FDM, AXP, CSCO, TGT, PLSE, TROW, ORCL,  FDX, CUBE, BABA, CTAS, ALK, JNJ, LLY, CB, NEE, FANG, GAMR, TWLO, TNA,  LABU, FAS, CTRE, PEP, EBAY, DFS, GE, SNQP, MS, RF, AMG, HIG, BR, BEN,  ZNGA, COR, WWE, WYNN, VT, VTI, ELY, ADBE, SQ, TWTR, CVS, CRSP, QQ, NDLS,  WU, MTRX, PUTW, TECL, GM, NYMT, MU and NDAQ .

author: melongod
body:
Honestly, investing is the new gambling. It sounds like you got lucky. I would sell it and move on something safer and let it grow overtime. UNLESS you know everything about the business and company. Investing can be like stalking. You follow the company/industry like a hawk. Otherwise you're gambling.

I just told my friend who's new to investing to buy something that will never die as long as your alive.

 I would recommend Pep, Sbux, Mcd, intel, msft, amd for the new investor as I call them better than a "back account stocks."

There's a lot to learn and the #1 strategy is to buy and hold forever. And realize you'll never buy at the lowest low or sell at the highest high. 

Disclosure. I hold 35 TSLA shares. I use to hold 400. I spend hours reading everything about TSLA, cars, and EV and tech EVERYDAY....while it's paid off, i do not recommend the life style to many.

author: Memitim901
body:
They did have weapons of mass destruction, not the stockpiles the world intelligence agencies thought they had, but they certainly had usable amounts. 

The problem was two-fold; the Iraq's lied internally about how much they were producing because they wanted to make Saddam happy to avoid a firing squad and these internal lies were what the coalition intelligence community based their reports on, and the administration focused efforts on those reports to link Iraq to al-qaeda as perpetrators of 9/11 which would have been a stretch even if the Intel reports were accurate.

author: TheThanatosGambit
body:
From the little DD I've done here's what I know:

MRVL's revenue still relies heavily on the dwindling HDD market. And though it's taking steps to reduce its reliance, their HDD/SDD sales currently account for over half of its revenue. Many of their SSD customers also happen to be their competitors, who are actively developing their own storage controllers. 

MRVL faces stiff competition in the networking and SSD hardware sectors, including such heavy hitters as Western Digital, Toshiba, Broadcom, and Intel. Though it recently (2018) acquired Cavium which extends its reach in the networking hardware market.

Management faced its share of controversy prior to 2016. It has since been replaced, however, and its acquisition of Cavium seems to indicate they're taking positive steps to gain strategic advantages, primarily in the networking market. 

I personally wouldn't consider them the "next Apple stock". They have a very long uphill battle to establish a secure market foothold, let alone establish market dominance. They don't have much diversity either, so any downturns that affect their product lines will hit them particularly hard. 

They do seem to be poised for long term growth, but with a notable level of uncertainty.

I’d bet a majority of those companies have under 10 hosts.

author: p_giggles
body:
I'd say that because companies which are heavily shorted are often smaller companies, there isn't a lot of other (non-financial) recognition. So if people can't find much besides a "short the shit out of this company" report, it might be more important for management to attempt to keep the stock afloat, whether it's in their own self interest or not.

If you try to short Intel it's a bit of a different story considering there are 40 analysts covering it and an ungodly amount of brand recognition. If one analyst comes out with a short and 39 say Intel is fine, it's unlikely the short piece actually does anything. But if you have three analysts covering you, which is very common for small-cap companies, one short piece can actually fuck your shit up. 

Also since companies often use their equity as collateral for a loan, the higher stock price could afford more reasonable loan terms, which could help the company's actual business.

author: boon4376
body:
When Jim Keller goes to work somewhere, you know that in 2-3 years that company will be cranking out new game changing products. Apple / AMD / Tesla.

Jim joined Intel in 2018 after leaving Tesla. Presumably to help Intel get their shit together. I'd anticipate we'll see Intel come roaring back starting in 2021.

Jim coordinates chip makers into a well oiled machine. 

Hopefully AMD's architecture and practices that Jim left in place have legs to keep up with whatever Intel develops.

author: DangerousDan4
MrOaiki
body: You’re right. And I can’t give you any such list because I can’t foresee the future. But I do believe there are moments in history where it is obvious to some that a new era is coming, an era that will last for decades. Ford and their cars would overtake personal transportation, Boeing would be the start of commercial travel by air, Microsoft and Intel would be part of the personal computer era, and Amazon and Google was the start of an era of online business giants. I like to think I would see it coming if I was old enough. But I’m probably fooled by a confirmation bias, and I’m not saying that sarcastically.

author: reuhop
body:
NKE (Nike) - 23%

My best performing stock. Bought at $70 and am up 44%. Nike will benefit from increased online sales. Their website and app allow them to sell directly to consumers. Nike is one of the best brands in the world. People are willing to pay a premium for their products. 

BABA (Alibaba) - 20%

Just bought this yesterday. This company is a massive growth and profit engine. Sales grew 46% per year on average over 5 years. EPS grew average 42% past 5 years. Profit margin 29%. I used to drop ship from Alibaba to Amazon and was amazed by this company. It's basically the world supplier. 

ULTA (Ulta Beauty) - 18% 

Ulta is one of the few retailers that Amazon won't destroy. Women like to try on makeup before they buy it. Ulta is a first stop for women when buying every day makeup. Their revenue and EPS growth have been steady and solid. 

DIS (Disney) - 18%

Disney+ has been a huge success and could catch up with Netflix. Disney owns so much great content and they're making it exclusive on Disney+.

ATVI (Activision) - 15%

COD Warzone has been a great hit. Several coworkers have been talking about it. I think investors are over estimating how much Q1 earnings were positively impacted by coronavirus. I think future earnings will be higher than expected because of Warzone. 

INTL (Intel) - 4% 

Intel may have a bad reputation with PC chips, but half their revenue comes from data centers. Their data center group grew 43% YOY. Cloud computing is the future. It gives any crappy computer access to super computer processing. Data centers are a highly profitable business. Intel has a 30% profit margin. With a p/e of 12, Intel is highly under valued.  I'm adding more to this one.

No.  I am a bull but this rally is fucked up and based on nothing and is not going to last.  I've been cashing out stuff again.  Sick of people posting juvenile "duh they just mad they ain't in it like me" comments.  No.  We're weirded out why the market (temporarily) being completely disconnected from reality.

author: w1na
body:
She did a good job, no one could even imagine even 5 years ago where AMD would be today.
When she took office, the cupboard were bare, there was no sales, no good architecture, losing for 2 decade to intel. Since the first athlon x64, they kept releasing bad products most of the time. In just 3 years, she made AMD go from Zero to Hero!

AMD now trading at tremendous numbers, no one thought would be possible ever. Heck just look 7 years back, the share price was about 2 bucks.

If there is any CEO who you feel should earn so much, it’s not people from Moderna, but Lisa Su.

Just to give you an idea, back in 2014 or so, I remember trying to buy AMD shares under 2 euros each (I wanted to get 2000 euro), before the order went through, it asked me for some paperwork confirmation, I then did not go through with the order and never did.

Missed on 1000 shares from AMD. I did not believe back then, although I saw it was incredibly cheap.

author: mechtech
body:
Well this is /r/investing, so buy quality and hold, diversify (beyond just bonds which may or may not have a good future in a zero rate world), and have worldwide exposure/don't arbitrarily lock yourself to your own country.

I actively trade, but in all likelihood in 2040 the investors at the top will likely have stories like "As Waymo got bigger, my ETF kept buying more, and now Waymo is 10 trillion dollars. And as that Chinese electric car company grew and took 1/3 of the 1 billion person Chinese market, my ETF kept buying more on the way up."

Although in that same vein, getting ahead of the tech curve might be one of the few ways for someone outside of the professional investor/institutional world to realistically get ahead. The trick is having the fortitude to hold for 1-2 decades. The financial crisis in '08 blew me out of so many hilariously good positions, like SBAC because the iPhone was just invented and 3G means more cell phone towers... It's not always rocket science. Anyone with some specialized insight into the future, whatever it may be, should consider putting a small well thought out speculative position on and leave it be. Small enough to not hurt if it goes nowhere, but big enough to care enough to check up and manage every few months.

Wow, just looked up an email from over 10 years ago. These names are probably in the mainstream investing language now, but wow... 10-100x if they were held. And it wasn't complex quant investing or anything, just looking ahead, positioning, and waiting.

Quotes from the email circa 10 years ago: "NVDA... They are also making a leap into scientific computing, where there's a lot of money to be made. They're the first major player to enter that arena to fight Intel and AMD in a long time, and their architecture is much more suited to scientific computing than the traditional CPUs that currently rule the top 100 supercomputer list. I think I'll see how that works out before selling NVDA"

"I might want to put some money in AMD as well. They're here to stay and may still be undervalued..."

"Universal Display Corp and LG Display (PANL/LPL) are also the leaders and partners in OLED screen development, which is bound to catch on eventually. Lower power use and much better image quality mean that it's just a matter of time before more devices adopt this new display technology and it becomes a new standard. I actually expect Apple to eventually partner up with LG (I think LG is their main LCD supplier) and use and use an OLED display on either a new product or a new Iphone version, which will kick OLED production into overdrive."

Food for thought... MicroLED is likely going to grow 1000x over the coming decades. AR and LIDAR sensors for AR will probably not just be used for face unlock and will get some killer apps, the next Snapchat or TikTok might be AR based. Self-Driving is going to be powered by thousands of companies, not just NVIDIA and Waymo. Quantum computing? AI providers in the military contracting space? Clean cargo ship tech to get in front of green regulations? It's endless, and so many people know about these little niches of information that very few others do. Even mundane spaces see world changing innovation every day. Getting in front of a curve is inherently speculative but it is also entertaining, educational to follow through development, and can be extremely profitable.

That's my appeal for pulling a few pennies out of the ETF pile and doing some a little different, especially if you have a "wheelhouse" that you know a little bit more about.

author: TripleBrain
body:
Now why the fuck exactly would any company that’s not the size of intel, Apple, ibm etc need 150 hosts??? You know the point of a host right? It’s to host a meeting. You really think anyone will need to host 150 meetings in the same time frame? Hell no.

And aside from that, you know these are not gonna be large companies because they won’t be categorizing it as “companies with 10+” employees. That’s like using inches to measure a mile. 
I’d bet a majority of those companies have under 10 hosts.

author: p_giggles
body:
I'd say that because companies which are heavily shorted are often smaller companies, there isn't a lot of other (non-financial) recognition. So if people can't find much besides a "short the shit out of this company" report, it might be more important for management to attempt to keep the stock afloat, whether it's in their own self interest or not.

If you try to short Intel it's a bit of a different story considering there are 40 analysts covering it and an ungodly amount of brand recognition. If one analyst comes out with a short and 39 say Intel is fine, it's unlikely the short piece actually does anything. But if you have three analysts covering you, which is very common for small-cap companies, one short piece can actually fuck your shit up. 

Also since companies often use their equity as collateral for a loan, the higher stock price could afford more reasonable loan terms, which could help the company's actual business.

When Jim Keller goes to work somewhere, you know that in 2-3 years that company will be cranking out new game changing products. Apple / AMD / Tesla.

Jim joined Intel in 2018 after leaving Tesla. Presumably to help Intel get their shit together. I'd anticipate we'll see Intel come roaring back starting in 2021.

Jim coordinates chip makers into a well oiled machine. 

Hopefully AMD's architecture and practices that Jim left in place have legs to keep up with whatever Intel develops.
